Janet Finch-Saunders AM, Deputy Minister for Health and Social Services, addressed the concerns raised by the Deputy Minister regarding the need for a public awareness campaign to raise awareness of the change in the law, stating that it was important for the public to be aware of the implications of the law change. She also highlighted the importance of ensuring that the public understands the impact of the Bill and the need to promote public awareness. The Deputy Minister emphasized that the Bill was not intended to create a new criminal offence, but rather to change the existing law, and that it should not be seen as a new offence. However, it is important to note that it is not a criminal offence for a child to be physically punished, as it is a criminal offense for a parent to physically punish their child, and there is a duty to educate the public about the change to the law. Additionally, it was emphasised that the law should be amended to ensure that children are not subjected to physical punishment if they have been physically punished in the past, as this could lead to a negative impact on their education and employment opportunities. I believe that this is the only way to achieve the objectives of this Bill, and I am confident that it will have a positive impact on the lives of children and their families. I also believe that the introduction of the new law will not result in a significant increase in the number of children being sent to carers, as there is no evidence to suggest that this will lead to an increase in child abuse. I think it's important to focus on the positive impact of this law on children and families, and it is essential for the Welsh Government to address the concerns of parents and ensure that they are not penalised due to a weak awareness campaign. I'm asking for the support of Members for amendments 1 and 4, as these amendments are necessary to ensure the success of the awareness campaign, as well as ensuring that there are adequate safeguards in place to protect children from harm in the future.

The WJEC does provide what's required in a regulatory sense, and there are two things there—the specification, which tends to be very comprehensive in providing guidance in terms of drawing up a programme of teaching, and also exemplar assessments, which include marking, and those go to the regulator before they are published. The Welsh Government does invest a great deal in resources that we produce digitally in both languages simultaneously. Each new course has substantial teaching guidance, which includes a lot of useful information for teachers and pupils. And we run a professional development programme for teachers that is free of charge when courses are new, and then annually there is some charge for those events. And, in addition, I'm a governor of one of the schools that features in the video. So, item 2, then, today is our first session on the provision of textbooks and learning resources for pupils, which is a video of interviews with young people and teachers. The committee team has been out to take video evidence around Wales, and we're now going to watch the results of that on the screen. We'll move on now then to our evidence session, and I'm very pleased to welcome Gareth Pierce, chief executive of the Welsh Education Commission (WJEC), Mike Ebbsworth, assistant director educational support, Welsh Government, and Philip Blaker, Chief Executive of Qualifications Wales, to the stage. gareth pierce: I think the question of translation is an interesting one. I think perhaps we need to understand what causes the need for that, largely because comparable outcomes are designed for circumstances like this, where there's a change in a specification particularly, because there are any number of reasons, including resources, why performance may be different from one year to the next, but comparable outcomes is there to ensure that, all things being equal, if the cohorts have the same ability, the same grade should be awarded. Therefore, I think another interesting question is: can we discover what those additional resources are that are worth translating? And, certainly, it would be very unfortunate if there were a dozen Welsh-medium schools, for example, translating material from the same website independently of each other. If there are a few websites, or a few case studies, in this big external digital world, shouldn't we able to source those early? Because I don't think it's a good use of teachers' time. philip blaker: Yes, we invest substantially from the Welsh Government budget into digital resources, so, through the types of conversations that Mike mentioned, we develop approval criteria and we ask Welsh Government to submit their specifications against those approval criteria. We have a language services team including excellent editors and translators within the Welsh-language team and we work closely with external translators too, which facilitates a great many things. We've made a lot more use recently of speaking with teachers and the consortia, and ensuring then that we are focusing on those things that need that attention. llyr gruffydd am: But would you—? The question I'm asking is: would you still see that as a core part of your work, although it's not necessarily essential in regard to the provision that you're required to provide?

The group discussed the introduction of the new remote control project, including the concept decisions, the universal remote, parental control, games, and voice recognition. Kirsty williams am: I think it's important to note that the concept of universal remote control has been around for a long time, and it's a concept that has been used in a number of countries, including Australia, Canada, and the United States. However, it's not a universal concept, and we have to be mindful of the fact that it may not be universally accepted by all schools. We need to make sure that we have a good understanding of how it works, and that we are using it in a way that meets the needs of the children. We have to ensure that it is effective and that it's effective for all children, but we need to be careful not to lose sight of the need for the children who are eligible for free school meals. So, for instance, if I give you an example in your own region, Llyr: at Brynteg County Primary School, if you look at that primary school in Wrexham, their results for free-school-meal children at the end of their primary school period in school are equivalent to their non-free school-meal counterparts. One of the things that they've used their PDG for is to really focus on the concepts of growth mindset in school, so, they've trained all the teachers in, but what we know is that that has a disproportionate effect on those children who have to pay for school meals, and they have to demonstrate that they have a positive impact on the free school meal programme. We've had some quite strong evidence about how difficult that makes longer term planning difficult for a lot of schools and we've also been pointed in the direction of what's happened in England with the Ever 6, and I'm just wondering whether you're giving any thought to maybe changing that a little bit. I'm going to be absolutely straight and blunt with you: we're not in a position at the moment to be able to identify an additional £40 million to introduce an Ever 6. In fact, we'll be having a discussion later on today about decisions, going forward, for the next two years. darren millar am: It's just a very brief point in response to the $40 million price ticket that you just put on that. That's, of course, assuming that you maintain the current level of PDG, yes? Kirsty, do you think that there's a great enough awareness of how the PDG should be used at the coalface? And also, are you confident that consortia and others have the measures in place to ensure it is being used properly?

Sharon davies: I can only speak for Torfaen—we've been working really hard on our exclusions and working with our schools to ensure that the curriculum is broad and balanced, and accounts for every learner within the system, and we know that we have schools that are looking at their funding—they are behind, and they have to make these hard choices. And sometimes, they've have to look at every aspect within the school in terms of their learners, then, and that does place additional pressure on the schools, and sometimes they've had to look to other areas of the school to meet the needs of the learner. But there's a little bit of lag, trying to bring everybody up to the same, consistent level. But I think work is afoot in nearly all local authorities, as far as I'm aware. In terms of school accountability measures, do you think that they have had an impact on the rise in exclusions? sharon d Davies: When we're looking at the accountabilities, there’s a huge amount of pressures on schools to perform, and I think the whole culture that the schools are within does play an element of it to some—. We are seeing a change with the interim measures coming on board, but I think there's going to be a lag in the system before we see that having a knock-on effect on our learners, because, undoubtedly, there are pressures on school. lynne neagle am: So, you’ve seen an improvement since the capped 9 has been brought in? sh Sharon Davies: I think it's early to say, but certainly we're working towards that improvement. And on the additional learning needs side, whilst the Minister has currently made some more money available, if we look at experiences that have happened in England, in particular, because there are direct parallels there with legislation, we know from those experiences that ALN funding has become increasingly under pressure—there have been big issues around Tribunals, to the point where local authorities at one point almost gave up going to tribunals because they were losing them time and time again. Anybody got anything to add to that, or—? nick williams: May I answer this in Welsh? Sharon, we have a team-around-the-family approach. So, as you say, it's more complicated than just the child behaving in a certain way, or being school-anxious, whatever the issue is, so it's sort of bringing all of the agencies together to try and look at how we can proactively solve problems and support the families. Because nearly always, the behaviours that are demonstrated, or come out in schools, or whatever provision, is obviously probably greater in the home environment, so there is a whole—. sharon Davies: We've just developed a behaviour and well-being strategy, which, with schools, I know across Wales we've done a lot of training on adverse childhood experiences and trauma-informed practice, so at least people can perhaps better understand some of the reasons why this behaviour is coming through, whereas in the past—I'm thinking myself, now, as a teacher—they were just difficult behaviours.

Meilyr rowlands: I think it's important to recognise that there's a difference between a primary school and a secondary school, and we need to make sure that we have a good balance between the two. We need to ensure that secondary schools have the resources they need to meet the needs of their pupils, and that they have the support and support they need. I think there are a lot of challenges for secondary schools, but I think they're doing a good job, and I think that they're going to be able to meet their needs. suzy davies am: Can I just ask: is that based on your evidence around primary schools, where the sort of ethos that we've seen in the curriculum has been already articulated through the foundation phase? meilyr Rowlands: The track record I'm talking about is across the board, so it's very difficult to think of anything that's actually got worse over the last three or four years, but it's difficult to say that standards of provision is slipping. It might not be improving as quickly as we would like, but the purpose of major curriculum and, more generally, educational reform is to make everyone take that seriously, and there's work going on regarding the workload issue. A large number of schools and teachers and leaders have been part of preparing the new curriculum and all the associated work, as well as doing the day job. But also the time it takes for the headteacher and the senior staff to make those decisions can take their eye off the educational ball because they're looking at these financial and staffing issues. I hope that we will have an opportunity to talk about the positive aspects of the education system in Wales, because there is a number of good things we can report also. The primary sector, the special sector, post-16—there are many sectors that are doing robust research into the subject matter. So, there are lots of ways—we were talking about maybe converting people from primary into secondary, particularly in Welsh-medium, where there's currently a shortage. Just before going on to that, just to pick up on that last point that you made about the shortage of teachers and losing teachers during the first year of their training. Has Estyn done any themed work on that particular issue, or do you intend to do anything on that? Also, looking at the financial incentives and how they compare with the situation in England, for example; do we need, perhaps, to think about financial incentives, not just for specific subjects, but for going to schools where there are particular issues, perhaps? Meilyr Rowelands: Yes. I know that Professor Mick Waters is looking at this currently and we've had the discussion with him. Now, we are looking at initial teacher training, but we haven't looked at the first couple of years for many a year. And, for your information, I've commissioned a piece of work on this particular issue and that work will be published in due course.

The WJEC does provide what's required in a regulatory sense, and there are two things there—the specification, which tends to be very comprehensive in providing guidance in terms of drawing up a programme of teaching, and also exemplar assessments, which include marking, and those go to the regulator before they are published. The Welsh government does invest a great deal in resources that we produce digitally in both languages simultaneously. Each new course has substantial teaching guidance, which includes a lot of useful information for teachers and pupils. And we run a professional development programme for teachers that is free of charge when courses are new, and then annually there is some charge for those events. And, in addition, I'm a governor of one of the schools that features in the video. So, item 2, then, today is our first session on the provision of textbooks and learning resources for pupils, which is a video of interviews with young people and teachers. The committee team has been out to take video evidence around Wales, and we're now going to watch the results of that on the screen. We'll move on now then to our evidence session, and I'm very pleased to welcome Gareth Pierce, chief executive of the Welsh government, Mike Ebbsworth, assistant director educational support, Welsh Government, and Philip Blaker, Chief Executive of Qualifications Wales, to the stage. gareth pierce: I think the question of translation is an interesting one. I think perhaps we need to understand what causes the need for that because, as I mentioned earlier, there are so many resources available digitally in either Welsh or English at the same time. Perhaps an interesting question is: is that source useful for teachers, being able to draw resources from two sources? Another interesting question, I think, is—.The Welsh language, of course, is a language that is used in an educational context, but we are in a big world that's an English language world. I am very aware that many of the websites we refer to in our resources and many of our case studies, as was mentioned in that video, are available in English only. Therefore, it is important that we discover what those additional resources are that are worth translating, and that we are able to discover them independently of each other. We have a language services team including excellent editors and translators within the Welsh Government and we work closely with external translators and we use translation technology increasingly, which facilitates a great many things.

sally jenkins: We know that there are a lot of people who are concerned about the impact of this Bill on children, and we need to make sure that we have a clear definition of what constitutes corporal punishment, and it's important to ensure that it is consistent with the principles of the Bill. However, it is important to recognise that there is a need for clarity in terms of the definition, as well as ensuring that the Bill is well-considered and well-thought-out, and that it reflects the needs of children and their families. We also need to be mindful of the importance of ensuring that this Bill is implemented in a way that respects the rights of the child and their right to equality and respect for their rights. We need to recognise the need for the Bill to be well-written, well-reasoned, and well thought-out. We have to be aware of the fact that this is a complex issue, and there are many different views on how to address it, but it is clear that there needs to be clarity, and the Bill needs to address the issue of how to achieve it. The committee has already heard different views about whether there's clear evidence that physical punishment is harmful to children. How do you respond to that view, and is what you're calling for essential to be on the face of the bill? huw david: It's not essential for it to be in the Bill, but we would like to see it incorporated into the Bill in the future. What we know is that children themselves, as Alastair has already referred to, really find physical punishment demeaning and harmful, and for children it is an emotionally damaging experience. I think what we would also say is that, in the world that we work in, it's part of a continuum, and, whilst this is an element of how children are cared for, what we see is a continuum where an acceptance of how we treat children in a particular way perpetuates throughout our work. So, for us, this is about a natural progression of change in how we care for our children in Wales. For children's services at the very sharp end of this world, it brings a true clarity. This continues with an ambiguity in the way we treat our children and how we think about care, and this shift for us brings that very much needed clarity. We've had evidence from the equal protection network that the reasonable punishment defence undermines child protection and fails to protect children because it permits an arbitrary level of violence, which invades children's physical integrity, making it a potential pathway to more serious physical or sexual abuse, and you did refer to that just now. It is about how we see our smallest and most vulnerable people, and if it is acceptable it opens the door to those other, more extreme versions of violence. The current legislation has been criticised, obviously, by the UN concerning the defence of reasonable punishment still being within our current legislation, so, we will always—ADEW will always —ADEW would always—advocate that the Rights of the Child be upheld, so that is really the fundamental aspect of the statement from ADEW and the position of ADEW. I know that the Children (Abolition of Defence of Reasonable Punishment) (Wales) Measure 2011 made sure that article 3 and article 4, article 12 and article 37 were a focus in terms to making sure that the best interests of children were put first, that children expressing their views and opinions was a priority. And we know, for safeguarding purposes, that the express opinions of the children and expressing their opinions are a fundamental part of any safe environment, whether it be a school or college. If we're to progress with this, that has to be an option that is offered to every parent in Wales; that is—the position is really following that legal position under the Human Rights of Children and Young Persons (Welsh) Measure. Nothing to add at this stage, no? alastair birch: Bore da—bore da, bawb.

meilyr rowlands: I think that there are a lot of things that we can do to improve the performance of children who are eligible for free school meals, but we need to be careful not to over-prioritise, because we want to make sure that we are targeting the right children, and we want them to be able to access the funding. You referred to the fact that it is used, perhaps, to reach a slightly wider cohort than just those who are enrolled in schools, but you do feel that that balance, from your experience, is acceptable. It was being spent on children who were underachieve achieving, and one of the things we did notice in the first report was that much more funding was spent on boys than girls. And, of course, that raised the question immediately that it wasn't being spent then on children with disabilities, because those numbers are equal. However, we are seeing examples where the targeting isn't going just to children who receive free school meal funding, and I think we should be seeing examples of schools that are using the grant to support more able children, but they are not using it for children who need extra support. So, I think there is an opportunity for schools to use the grant in a different way, but I think they need to do it in a way that is more effective.

Angela burns am: So, let's start with a question about the financial situation of the universities in Wales, because we know that there are a lot of challenges facing the sector, and we have seen a rise in the number of students leaving the sector in recent years, and there are concerns about the sustainability of the sector as a whole. dr david blaney: We are seeing a significant increase in the amount of money that the universities have to spend, but we are not seeing a crisis, we're seeing really challenging circumstances for institutions to manage, and they are managing them, so one of the things we try to do is to make sure that, insofar as we can see it, we are making sure that the institutions are alert to the challenges they're facing, and are actually engaging those challenges properly. And we are seeing that at the moment. These challenges are not unique to Wales; the majority of the UK universities are actually taking out cost one way or another. Before the Diamond review, there was a pre-existing funding gap in resource between England and Wales, and even now, that's still the case. The forecasts that we had this time last year were indicating that, for 2018-19, we should have a sector that's roughly in a break-even position, but that has to be caveated with waiting for new forecasts in July, where there will have to be a reflection of the pension costs. And there have been significant changes in pension costs, both for the teachers' pension scheme and the universities' superannuation scheme as well. So, in the short term, the reserves of Cardiff will appear as though they have significant cash balances, but all of those are restricted for investment in the estate and, over the next two or three years, will be utilised for that. And against that backdrop, the introduction of the Diamond reforms is hugely important—delivery of that is going to be really important—and we are really pleased to see the Minister able to meet her commitments in respect of that. We have to understand, though, that taking out costs to balance the books has a detrimental effect on the capacity. Obviously it impacts on the people who lose their jobs immediately, but there's a medium to longer term impact on the capacities of the system to deliver for Wales. They are taking out capacity; they're not cutting at fat now, they're cutting out core capacity. And that represents their capacity to generate surplus cash to meet their costs, which now, increasingly, include the costs of servicing their borrowings. And so, again, because capital funding has not been as available to universities as it was, they've invested in their estates and that's largely been funded by borrowings, so that's becoming an increasing proportion of the operating cash that universities have. The costs of those borrowings have to meet on an annual basis, so those costs are becoming increasing proportionally, and that is increasing the cost of operating costs. angela burns Am: I just asked that question because I know that about four years ago, the universities were sitting on substantial reserves and were less than keen to deploy them back into actually using them for the students—it was more about building up the war chest, if you like, of the Universities. And I just really wanted to have an understanding of how that picture might have changed over the last four years and are they actually skinnier cats now, rather than before. bethan owen: We can get you that analysis, but I think the definition of exactly what's meant by reserves, it's really important to look at what are distributable reserves as opposed to the assets that Universities have.

I'm very pleased to welcome Meilyr Rowlands, Her Majesty's Chief Inspector, Estyn; Jassa Scott, Strategic Director at Estyn, and Claire Morgan, strategic director at EstYN. Thank you for the papers upfront, in which you say that the most striking feature of the education system, looking forward, of course is the curriculum and the change that that's bringing. How can we be sure that, during this period of change, standards don't slip? And also, from the point of view of scrutiny, will we be back in a situation where we're being told, 'You can't compare one set of results against the previous year's results, because of the nature of the change'? meilyr rowlands: Bore da, bawb. I think this process of reform has been going on in the background for a few years now, so I think there is a track record of standards and provision not slipping. So, overall, I think we can be fairly confident that standards won't slip during the period of preparation. suzy davies am: Can I just ask: is that based on your evidence around primary schools, where the sort of ethos that we've seen in the curriculum has been already articulated through the foundation phase?

Meilyr rowlands: I think it's important to remember that we have a lot of work to do, and we have to be careful not to get too hung up on the fact that there's a difference between the primary and secondary schools, because there are many different types of schools, and it's not just the primary schools that are affected by the new curriculum, but also the secondary schools as well. I think that there is a need to look at the whole system, and I think we need to make sure that we don't see any slippage in terms of standards and provision. We need to ensure that there are no bottlenecks in the system, but we also need to be mindful of the importance of ensuring that the system is in place for the future. suzy davies am: Okay, and on that point of comparing year on year, we will be able to make those comparisons legitimately then? Meilyr Rowlands: Yes, we can, and that's something that we're going to be doing in the next couple of years. I know that it's going to take some time for schools to get to grips with it, but I think they'll be well on their way, and they'll have the support they need to do it.

Hefin David am: I would like to start by asking Kirsty Williams AM to address the issue of whether schools will be able to reopen in the future. Kirsty williams am: It is important to note that we are currently in the process of assessing the impact of the pandemic on the education system, and we are working closely with the Department for Education and Skills to ensure that we have a plan in place to ensure the safety and security of children and young people. Hefin david am: So, Kirsty, could you elaborate on this? Kirsty Willams Am: I think it is important for me to make it clear that we will need to take a lead from our scientific and medical advisers, but from discussions that I've had with Universities Wales and vice-chancellors, they are very keen to be kept apprised of these approaches, because they may well wish to implement something similar within their own institutions. I've got a couple of supplementaries now; firstly, from Suzy Davies, and then I'm going to go to Siân Gwenllian, who is group director, skills, higher education and lifelong learning. I'm very pleased to welcome Kirsty William AM, Minister for Education, Steve Davies, Director of the education directorate, and Huw Morris, Director, Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning, to the meeting. I want to thank them for their support and understanding, and I look forward to working with them in the coming weeks to ensure a smooth and effective response to this pandemic. hefin david is: And could I just ask, with regard to the principles, do they then apply to further education and universities? kirsty Williams Am: Yes, they do apply to higher education, but they are not going to apply to universities, and they will only apply to schools and FE colleges.

meilyr rowlands: I think that there are a lot of things that we can do to improve the performance of these children, but we need to be careful not to over-prioritise, because we have to make sure that we are not over-targeting them, and that we don't spend too much time on the children who are not eligible for free school meals. I think it's important to focus on the more able and talented children, because they are the ones who are most likely to benefit from the grant, and I think there is a lot to be done to ensure that they get the support they need. llyr gruffydd am: Because the research by Ipsos MORI and the Wales Institute of Social and Economic Research, Data and Methods has shown that there is some kind of blurring—I think that's the term that they use—in terms of who is eligible. You've reported that the proportion of schools making effective use of the PDG remains around two thirds of secondary and primary schools, meaning that a third are still not using that funding effectively. Why do you think this is? meilyr Rowlands: It's a particular part of our inspection framework—looking at the relative performance of different groups. So, we look at the different performance of boys and girls, free and non-free school meals, ethnic minorities, and we also look at performance of more able pupils in particular. That's not to say that the targeting is working perfectly still, but I think we are seeing examples where the targeting isn't going just to children who receive free meals. In terms of what schools are doing with the funding, we have given evidence to you of the kinds of things they are doing. They are tracking progress of pupils, they're trying to improve attendance, they are trying to work with families and the community in general, and they're doing work specifically to improve how children are doing in exams, in key stage 4, specifically—a lot of funding is being spent on that—improving the confidence of students, taking students on extra-curricular activities, improving literacy and numeracy. It seems to be a strong correlation between children who underachieve and that measure, so it is a strong measure, for example, For example, some people say that if you have received free school meal for a period of time and now you're not receiving them, then perhaps you should still be receiving the funding for another period. However, if you are not receiving the money, then you shouldn't receive the money for a longer period, and you should be receiving it for a shorter period. We will move on then to item 2 on our agenda, the continuation of our inquiry into targeted funding to improve educational outcomes, and evidence session 8. Would you like to introduce yourselves for the record, please?

Kirsty williams am: I think it's important to be absolutely clear that when it comes to individual interventions, those individual interventions should only be targeted at those children who are eligible for free school meals, but in some cases, schools may use their PDG funding to provide a universal intervention, but we would want to have evidence that that universal intervention would have a disproportionate effect on the outcomes for children on free school meal meals. So, for instance, if I give you an example in your own region, Llyr: at Brynteg County Primary School in Wrexham, if you look at that primary school in Wales, their results for free-school-meal children at the end of their primary school period in school are equivalent to their non-free school-meal counterparts. One of the things that they've used PDG for is to really focus on the concept of growth mindset in school, so, that's a universal thing that they have trained all the teachers in, but what we know is that that has a disproportionate increase in the number of eligible children, and now they're at the same level. And obviously, we have been very clear with regional challenge advisers, in the relationship and the conversations they're having with individual schools, that they're really challenging their schools about the use of PDG, not just in terms of targeting, but the programmes, what the money is being spent on, whether there is an evidence base for that and whether we are clear on impact. llyr gruffydd am: And we all share those aspirations, I'm sure, and you pointed to examples of good practice, but of course, it's not universal, is it, so what I'm asking is: do you think that the guidance is sufficient as it is? Do you think there's a great enough awareness of how the PDG should be used at the coalface? And also, are you confident that consortia and others have the measures in place to be able to demonstrate that it is being used properly?

The first petition is from a group of residents of the Saanich Gulf Islands, who are concerned about the lack of adequate funding for their local schools. They also call on the Government of Canada to provide funding for schools to meet the needs of their families. The second petition is about the need for more funding for the school system, with a focus on education, and the third petition focuses on the importance of providing a safe environment for children to learn and grow. The petitioners want to see the government take action to ensure the safety and well-being of children in schools, as well as the safety of their parents and grandparents. The fourth and final petition deals with Bill S-204, a bill that would make it a criminal offence for a Canadian to go abroad and receive an organ from a person who has not consented to giving that organ. It would also create a mechanism by which someone could be deemed inadmissible to Canada if they were involved in organ harvesting and trafficking. the chair: Before proceeding to the next presenter, I will remind the honourable members in the chamber that I realize that the six-foot limit makes it harder to whisper to each other, but we're hearing a bit of rumble, so I just want you to try to whisper at your best. stphane bergeron (montarville, bq): Mr.Chair, on July1st, we will be celebrating one of the most important events for the riding of Montarville: the 175thanniversary of the city of Saint-Bruno-de-Montarville. The theme Proud of our traditions will be the focus of this celebration for the people of Montarlville. This is a good illustration of the rich history of this municipality nestled in the western foothills of Mont-Saint-Baseline. The seigneury of Montairville was granted in 1710 to the illustrious former governor of Trois-Rivires, PierreBoucher. The parish of St. Francis Xavier, which took root there and in which a village grew, became a municipal corporation in 1845. To this day, it is one of Canada's most prosperous localities with a strong sense of belonging, a very dynamic community life and jealously preserved natural environments. A whole program had been drawn up for the celebration, but the current health crisis has taken over some of the planned activities, which has in no way diminished the pride and festive spirit of the people. Chair, thank you for allowing me to take a moment to highlight an initiative that I started early on during the COVID-19 pandemic. The Heroes of Etobicoke-Lakeshore is an opportunity for citizens in my riding to recognize the contributions of those in their community who make life a bit easier. I'm pleased with the number of nominations I received that honour everyone from front-line workers to businesses that are innovating in these difficult times to volunteers who are finding new ways to reach out. I think of Daniel Lauzon who set up Food for Now, a mobile service that helps take care of the homeless. The increases to the GIS by $200, and $300 to the OAS, have been well received. They just want to highlight how important it is to support our seniors, in particular the poorest of our seniors. The chair: For members present in the Chamber, a reminder that they are asked to bring their petitions to the table. I remind members that any petition presented during a meeting of this special committee must have already been certified by the clerk of petitions. For members participating in person, I ask that they please come and drop their signed certificates off at the table once the petition is presented. I would ask members to be very brief and concise, and to summarize the exact content of the petition. The first petition was from petitioners who are very concerned about our obligations under the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples and our commitments under the Truth and Reconciliation Commission calls to action. They specifically reference the RCMP violation of UNDRIP in its actions on Wet'suwet'en territory and ask the Government to commit to actually living the principles embodied in the UN Declaration. I am presenting a petition on behalf of the one in a million Canadians who suffer severe and adverse effects from vaccinations. Even before the crisis, they would often share the hardships they faced on a day-to-day basis.

The Welsh bac is considered to be an important qualification for Welsh students, as it prepares them for employment. However, it has been criticised by some employers, who feel that it does not meet their needs and that it is not aligned with the Welsh baccalaureate qualification, which they believe should be the focus of the qualification. They believe that it should be a qualification that prepares students for employment, rather than a vocational qualification, and they are concerned about the lack of support they receive from schools and colleges. They are concerned that it may not meet the needs of employers, and that they may not be able to find a place for their children in the workforce. They have concerns about the quality of the qualifications that are being provided to Welsh students. They feel that they are not adequately preparing their children for employment and that there is a need for more support for them. They also feel that there are other qualifications that can be provided to prepare them for work, such as vocational qualifications. They want to know what they need to do in order to be successful in their jobs, and it is important for them to have a good understanding of the skills that they need. They would also like to know if they are ready for work and whether they have the right skills for the job market. They're having enough headache getting around the differences with apprenticeships and the levy between England and Wales, and changes to qualifications. But they want them to get their main qualification. The aim is an excellent one, but I think we've lost our way in terms of what we do present at the end of the day, and I think having more input from employers would be a great help. I think there are opportunities to join up employers and schools and education facilities a lot more than we do at the moment. And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand, the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business. And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh Bac, what does it offer. And, certainly, when that's evolved over the past few years and there have been changes, it would have been quite difficult to keep up to date with those, I imagine. nick brazil: Could I add to that? As do many of my colleagues within the colleges, we have a number of employer boards, which we regularly meet with—employers—and I cannot think back as to how many employers say to us, 'That is what we require—the Welsh bachelorette—to come and work within our industry.' Most of what they are questioning is the level of professional qualifications and the Quality of skills within those professional sectors. So, I think it's important for us to make sure that we are providing the right qualifications for employers.
